elements.content: Simple, efficient conversion of viable Fe3+-based metallogels into Fe-metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has been achieved by PdCl2-mediated gel degradation. The metallogels and the resulting MOFs have been characterized, and a probable mechanism for the event has been elucidated.
elements.clean_text: Simple, efficient conversion of viable Fe3+-based metallogels into Fe-metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been achieved by PdCl2-mediated gel degradation. The metallogels and the resulting MOFs have been characterized, and a probable mechanism for the event has been elucidated.

elements.content:
Simple, efficient transformation of viable Fe3+-metallogels into Fe-metal−organic frameworks has been achieved via PdCl2-mediated metallogel degradation.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising materials for a myriad of applications viz., gas adsorption, separation and storage, sensors, catalysis, drug delivery, luminescence, etc., owing to their tunable surface area and pore size. MOF synthesis begins with the meticulous choice of suitable metal ions and ligands which dictate their ultimate properties. Among the most widely studied MOFs, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, and Zn-based MOFs mainly dominate the list followed by Ca-, Mn-, and Mg-based MOFs. In spite of being a cheap and abundantly available ion, limited examples of Fe-based MOFs exist in the literature owing to the easy oxidation of Fe2+ and ready hydrolysis of Fe3+ under hydrothermal conditions which poses a grand challenge for their bulk synthesis. Currently, a handful of protocols exist for large-scale synthesis of Fe-MOFs, particularly the MIL-n (Fe3+)series. However, most of these procedures suffer from synthetic constraints such as the use of toxic HF/HNO3, and most of their structures are determined from the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns owing to the difficulty in the formation of mountable-sized single crystals. This demands a look out for a facile method to improve the scalability as well as size of such MOF crystals so as to make the crystal structure determination easier, which is essentially needed to understand the MOF structure–property relationship.
elements.clean_text:
Simple, efficient transformation of viable Fe3+-metallogels into Fe-metal-organic frameworks has been achieved via PdCl2-mediated metallogel degradation.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising materials for a myriad of applications viz., gas adsorption, separation and storage, sensors, catalysis, drug delivery, luminescence, etc., owing to their tunable surface area and pore size. MOF synthesis begins with the meticulous choice of suitable metal ions and ligands which dictate their ultimate properties. Among the most widely studied MOFs, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, and Zn-based MOFs mainly dominate the list followed by Ca-, Mn-, and Mg-based MOFs. In spite of being a cheap and abundantly available ion, limited examples of Fe-based MOFs exist in the literature owing to the easy oxidation of Fe2+ and ready hydrolysis of Fe3+ under hydrothermal conditions which poses a grand challenge for their bulk synthesis. Currently, a handful of protocols exist for large-scale synthesis of Fe-MOFs, particularly the MIL-n (Fe3+)series. However, most of these procedures suffer from synthetic constraints such as the use of toxic HF/HNO3, and most of their structures are determined from the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns owing to the difficulty in the formation of mountable-sized single crystals. This demands a look out for a facile method to improve the scalability as well as size of such MOF crystals so as to make the crystal structure determination easier, which is essentially needed to understand the MOF structure-property relationship.

elements.content: One of the ways to improve the crystal size and growth is the use of traditional sol–gel technique wherein an inert gel matrix maintains the crystal nuclei in its position of formation and growth. On attainment of a mountable size, the crystals are recovered by dissolution of the gel matrix, induced by the external physical or chemical factors. However, in the case of MOFs, which essentially needs an inorganic metal ion along with an organic strut, screening an inert matrix that could be later dissolved leaving the MOFs unharmed would be a daunting task. One such synthesis was attempted by Yaghi et al., wherein an inert nonaqueous gelling solvent was used for growing a three-dimensional (3D) MOF, Zn (HBTC)­(NC5H5)2­·C2H5OH. Recently Lloyd and co-workers reported crystallization of small coordination compounds such as metallocycles from the gelling solvent itself. This phenomenon could be used in the case of Fe-MOF systems wherein gelation of a Fe-ligand solution is observed in some of the regularly used organic solvents such as DMF, ethanol, methanol, etc. On degradation, such metallogel systems could act as a reservoir for furnishing the needed metal ions as well as organic linkers for in situ MOF formation. Nonetheless, this metallogel to MOF conversion remains largely unexplored for MOF synthesis. Moreover, inducing crystallization in such stable metallogel systems would be challenging as they are well-known for their high thermal and chemical stability. Herein, we present a new strategy for the synthesis of Fe-MOFs via PdCl2-mediated gel-to-crystal transformation from substituted formamide analogues, namely, NMF, DMF, or DEF, an approach rarely followed to synthesize MOFs.
elements.clean_text: One of the ways to improve the crystal size and growth is the use of traditional sol-gel technique wherein an inert gel matrix maintains the crystal nuclei in its position of formation and growth. On attainment of a mountable size, the crystals are recovered by dissolution of the gel matrix, induced by the external physical or chemical factors. However, in the case of MOFs, which essentially needs an inorganic metal ion along with an organic strut, screening an inert matrix that could be later dissolved leaving the MOFs unharmed would be a daunting task. One such synthesis was attempted by Yaghi et al., wherein an inert nonaqueous gelling solvent was used for growing a three-dimensional (3D) MOF, Zn (HBTC)(NC5H5)2⋅C2H5OH. Recently Lloyd and co-workers reported crystallization of small coordination compounds such as metallocycles from the gelling solvent itself. This phenomenon could be used in the case of Fe-MOF systems wherein gelation of a Fe-ligand solution is observed in some of the regularly used organic solvents such as DMF, ethanol, methanol, etc. On degradation, such metallogel systems could act as a reservoir for furnishing the needed metal ions as well as organic linkers for in situ MOF formation. Nonetheless, this metallogel to MOF conversion remains largely unexplored for MOF synthesis. Moreover, inducing crystallization in such stable metallogel systems would be challenging as they are well-known for their high thermal and chemical stability. Herein, we present a new strategy for the synthesis of Fe-MOFs via PdCl2-mediated gel-to-crystal transformation from substituted formamide analogues, namely, NMF, DMF, or DEF, an approach rarely followed to synthesize MOFs.

elements.content: The synthesis involves a simple one-pot, two-step process, wherein the MOF precursors, viz., 0.1 mmol of Fe (NO3)3·9H2O and 0.1 mmol of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (in ratio 1:3), are dissolved in 1.5 mL of NMF, DMF, and DEF (). The gelation results within 6 h of heating at 90 °C, following which 0.1 mmol of PdCl2 (dissolved in the corresponding solvent) is added to the metallogel. The vials are again kept at 90 °C for heating. The degradation of gel begins after 24 h, and the MOF formation results after 48 h. The MOF crystals were then separated by gentle sonication and repeated washing with the solvent used for the synthesis. The yield obtained amounts to ∼80% in each case.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis involves a simple one-pot, two-step process, wherein the MOF precursors, viz., 0.1 mmol of Fe (NO3)3⋅9H2O and 0.1 mmol of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (in ratio 1:3), are dissolved in 1.5 mL of NMF, DMF, and DEF (). The gelation results within 6 h of heating at 90 °C, following which 0.1 mmol of PdCl2 (dissolved in the corresponding solvent) is added to the metallogel. The vials are again kept at 90 °C for heating. The degradation of gel begins after 24 h, and the MOF formation results after 48 h. The MOF crystals were then separated by gentle sonication and repeated washing with the solvent used for the synthesis. The yield obtained amounts to ~80% in each case.

elements.content: The gelation of Fe-BTC solution was verified by a simple inversion-tube test (Figure ). The resulting metallogels were found to be robust with no visible weakening observed over weeks. The opaque gels obtained were further investigated using rheology studies. The inherent viscoelastic and brittle nature was established by oscillatory rheological measurements (Figure and ). Dynamic frequency (DFS) and strain sweep (DSS) show that the average storage modulus (G′) was one order of magnitude higher than the loss modulus (G″) within the linear viscoelastic regime (for Fe-BTC-NMF and Fe-BTC-DMF gels) and consistent over the whole range of frequency (Figure ). DFS and DSS also exhibit the weaker nature of the Fe-BTC-DEF gel compared to the other two samples (Fe-BTC-NMF and Fe-BTC-DMF, with the difference between storage and loss modulus being less than 1 order of magnitude). The low value storage and viscous moduli (G′ and G″) indicate that the gels are weak in nature. In this perspective, the brittle nature of the metallogels was concluded by their fracture at strain (deformation) below 100%. The E-SEM images of the Fe-BTC-NMF metallogels showed the presence of long fibrillar network (Figure ), while that of Fe-BTC-DEF and Fe-BTC-DMF exhibited aggregation of thick gel fibers. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that the metallogels showed high thermal stability with weight losses of ∼20% corresponding to the solvent losses observed at a broad range of temperature (115–630 °C), as the solvent molecules are loosely bound to the metallogel network ().
elements.clean_text: The gelation of Fe-BTC solution was verified by a simple inversion-tube test (Figure ). The resulting metallogels were found to be robust with no visible weakening observed over weeks. The opaque gels obtained were further investigated using rheology studies. The inherent viscoelastic and brittle nature was established by oscillatory rheological measurements (Figure  and ). Dynamic frequency (DFS) and strain sweep (DSS) show that the average storage modulus (G') was one order of magnitude higher than the loss modulus (G") within the linear viscoelastic regime (for Fe-BTC-NMF and Fe-BTC-DMF gels) and consistent over the whole range of frequency (Figure ). DFS and DSS also exhibit the weaker nature of the Fe-BTC-DEF gel compared to the other two samples (Fe-BTC-NMF and Fe-BTC-DMF, with the difference between storage and loss modulus being less than 1 order of magnitude). The low value storage and viscous moduli (G' and G") indicate that the gels are weak in nature. In this perspective, the brittle nature of the metallogels was concluded by their fracture at strain (deformation) below 100%. The E-SEM images of the Fe-BTC-NMF metallogels showed the presence of long fibrillar network (Figure ), while that of Fe-BTC-DEF and Fe-BTC-DMF exhibited aggregation of thick gel fibers. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that the metallogels showed high thermal stability with weight losses of ~20% corresponding to the solvent losses observed at a broad range of temperature (115-630 °C), as the solvent molecules are loosely bound to the metallogel network ().

elements.content: Schematic representation of conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-MOFs via PdCl2-mediated gel degradation.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic representation of conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-MOFs via PdCl2-mediated gel degradation.

elements.content: Combined strain-dependent studies of Fe-BTC-DMF, Fe-BTC-DEF, and Fe-BTC-NMF gels.
elements.clean_text: 2  Combined strain-dependent studies of Fe-BTC-DMF, Fe-BTC-DEF, and Fe-BTC-NMF gels.

elements.content: E-SEM of gels [(a), (b), (c)], SEM images [(d), (e), (f)], and corresponding single crystal structure of Fe-BTC-NMF, Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF, and Fe-BTC-DMF systems, respectively (color code: Fe: orange, O: red, C: gray, N: blue, Pd: green).
elements.clean_text: 3  E-SEM of gels [(a), (b), (c)], SEM images [(d), (e), (f)], and corresponding single crystal structure of Fe-BTC-NMF, Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF, and Fe-BTC-DMF systems, respectively (color code: Fe: orange, O: red, C: gray, N: blue, Pd: green).

elements.content: The single crystal structures of the Fe-MOFs resulting from the degradation of the metallogels were analyzed, and two new MOFs, namely, Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF (3D) and Fe-BTC-NMF (2D), were obtained, in addition to the known Fe-BTC-DMF MOF. Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF crystallized in hexagonal space group P63/mmc () and the secondary building unit (SBU) contains two metal centers, Fe(II) and Pd(II). In the extended structure, one set of Fe centers is tetrahedrally coordinated to four O atoms, and another Fe is coordinated to five O atoms forming a square pyramidal geometry. The Pd(II) adopts a square planar geometry and is coordinated with four C atoms of CO molecules. The CO molecules found in the crystal structure is possibly generated along the pathway of formic/formamide oxidation as confirmed from the GC analysis. On the other hand, Fe- BTC-NMF crystallized in trigonal space group R3̅ (see ) forming a two-dimensional (2D) structure. In the extended crystal structure, Fe3+ adopts an octahedral geometry coordinated to five oxygens from μ2-CO2 – functionalities of BTC and one NMF oxygen atom. The as-synthesized crystals of Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF were found to be very unstable and readily converted into some unidentifiable precipitates when taken out of the solution and thus the PXRD pattern could not be obtained. The PXRD patterns of the other two MOFs match well with their simulated ones which confirm that the product obtained are in their pure crystalline forms (). From the IR spectra, a red shift of the ligand CO stretching could be observed, which indicates the formation of Fe ← C–O bonding during gelation followed by crystallization of MOF ().The SEM images of the Fe-MOFs reported in this paper revealed the formation of crystals with well-defined faces with reduced palladium residues observed in the case of Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF (Figure , ).
elements.clean_text: The single crystal structures of the Fe-MOFs resulting from the degradation of the metallogels were analyzed, and two new MOFs, namely, Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF (3D) and Fe-BTC-NMF (2D), were obtained, in addition to the known Fe-BTC-DMF MOF. Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF crystallized in hexagonal space group P63/mmc () and the secondary building unit (SBU) contains two metal centers, Fe(II) and Pd(II). In the extended structure, one set of Fe centers is tetrahedrally coordinated to four O atoms, and another Fe is coordinated to five O atoms forming a square pyramidal geometry. The Pd(II) adopts a square planar geometry and is coordinated with four C atoms of CO molecules. The CO molecules found in the crystal structure is possibly generated along the pathway of formic/formamide oxidation as confirmed from the GC analysis. On the other hand, Fe- BTC-NMF crystallized in trigonal space group R3̅ (see ) forming a two-dimensional (2D) structure. In the extended crystal structure, Fe3+ adopts an octahedral geometry coordinated to five oxygens from μ2-CO2 - functionalities of BTC and one NMF oxygen atom. The as-synthesized crystals of Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF were found to be very unstable and readily converted into some unidentifiable precipitates when taken out of the solution and thus the PXRD pattern could not be obtained. The PXRD patterns of the other two MOFs match well with their simulated ones which confirm that the product obtained are in their pure crystalline forms (). From the IR spectra, a red shift of the ligand CO stretching could be observed, which indicates the formation of Fe ← C-O bonding during gelation followed by crystallization of MOF ().The SEM images of the Fe-MOFs reported in this paper revealed the formation of crystals with well-defined faces with reduced palladium residues observed in the case of Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF (Figure , ).

elements.content: In the present work, solvents, namely, NMF, DMF, DEF, were preferred as they have always been attractive choices for MOF synthesis by the virtue of their high boiling points and partial hydrolytic decomposition into corresponding amines and formic acid at higher temperature. The in situ amines thus formed have proven to deprotonate the ligand and in turn ruling out the need for an additional base. Conversely, the fate of the other product, i.e., formic acid formed during the course of the reaction or gelation as in this case, and its role, if any, has been hardly studied except in a few cases where the formate ion is found coordinated to the metal ion in the crystal structure. A case study on formic acid substantiated the use of noble metal ions, viz., Ag+, Pd2+, Pt4+, etc., for its oxidation. Thus, a study was attempted using a palladium-based salt, PdCl2. To our surprise, on addition of PdCl2, the metallogels began to develop turbidity and later degraded into a sol. The onset of metallogel degradation was associated with the formation of palladium black (confirmed from PXRD, ). The degradation of metallogel completed within 2–3 days following which large sized crystals were obtained.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, solvents, namely, NMF, DMF, DEF, were preferred as they have always been attractive choices for MOF synthesis by the virtue of their high boiling points and partial hydrolytic decomposition into corresponding amines and formic acid at higher temperature. The in situ amines thus formed have proven to deprotonate the ligand and in turn ruling out the need for an additional base. Conversely, the fate of the other product, i.e., formic acid formed during the course of the reaction or gelation as in this case, and its role, if any, has been hardly studied except in a few cases where the formate ion is found coordinated to the metal ion in the crystal structure. A case study on formic acid substantiated the use of noble metal ions, viz., Ag+, Pd2+, Pt4+, etc., for its oxidation. Thus, a study was attempted using a palladium-based salt, PdCl2. To our surprise, on addition of PdCl2, the metallogels began to develop turbidity and later degraded into a sol. The onset of metallogel degradation was associated with the formation of palladium black (confirmed from PXRD, ). The degradation of metallogel completed within 2-3 days following which large sized crystals were obtained.

elements.content: To decipher the mechanism of gel degradation, the reaction was monitored on Fe-BTC-DMF gel using gas chromatography (GC). As shown in Figure , GC evaluation on the first day (metallogel phase) did not show the presence of any gaseous products. On addition of PdCl2, evolution of CO2 and CO along with traces of H2 was observed. The rate of evolution increased from the second to third day (phase of metallogel degradation and onset of nucleation) and was steady after that. This was accompanied by MOF formation, and mountable-sized crystals could be obtained at the end of the third day. The presence of formic acid oxidation products CO2, CO, and H2 along with palladium black, confirmed that PdCl2 underwent reduction mediating the degradation of the metallogels (). However, direct evidence to detect the presence of formic acid/formate ion in the system failed as the DMF solvent also gave positive results to the silver mirror test, usually tried formic acid test reaction. This could be due to the Lewis acid nature of the Ag+ which brings about DMF degradation thereby resulting in the in situ formation of formic acid, which eventually reduces Ag+ to Ag. A similar reaction in the presence of PdCl2 renders the formation of palladium mirror (). The gel degradation could also be observed during addition of all known formic acid oxidation reagents, namely, Pd(OAc)2, AgNO3, and H2PtCl4 addition. However, the quality of the obtained crystals was the best with PdCl2. The phenomenon could not be observed when tried with chloride salts of other metals, namely, NaCl and NiCl2. This hints at the presence of an oxidative pathway and its involvement in bringing about the degradation of the metallogel (Figure ). It is, however, intricate to exactly determine the usefulness of formic acid and the role of DMF apart from being a solvent for gelation.

As shown in Figure , GC evaluation on the first day (metallogel phase) did not show the presence of any gaseous products. On addition of PdCl2, evolution of CO2 and CO along with traces of H2 was observed. The rate of evolution increased from the second to third day (phase of metallogel degradation and onset of nucleation) and was steady after that. This was accompanied by MOF formation, and mountable-sized crystals could be obtained at the end of the third day. The presence of formic acid oxidation products CO2, CO, and H2 along with palladium black, confirmed that PdCl2 underwent reduction mediating the degradation of the metallogels (). However, direct evidence to detect the presence of formic acid/formate ion in the system failed as the DMF solvent also gave positive results to the silver mirror test, usually tried formic acid test reaction. This could be due to the Lewis acid nature of the Ag+ which brings about DMF degradation thereby resulting in the in situ formation of formic acid, which eventually reduces Ag+ to Ag. A similar reaction in the presence of PdCl2 renders the formation of palladium mirror (). The gel degradation could also be observed during addition of all known formic acid oxidation reagents, namely, Pd(OAc)2, AgNO3, and H2PtCl4 addition. However, the quality of the obtained crystals was the best with PdCl2. The phenomenon could not be observed when tried with chloride salts of other metals, namely, NaCl and NiCl2. This hints at the presence of an oxidative pathway and its involvement in bringing about the degradation of the metallogel (Figure ). It is, however, intricate to exactly determine the usefulness of formic acid and the role of DMF apart from being a solvent for gelation.

elements.content: Bar graphs representing the evolution of (a) CO2, (b) H2, and (c) CO gases collected from the first to third day during PdCl2-mediated conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-metal organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: 4  Bar graphs representing the evolution of (a) CO2, (b) H2, and (c) CO gases collected from the first to third day during PdCl2-mediated conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-metal organic frameworks.

elements.content: Schematic representation of mechanism illustrating the conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-metal organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: 5  Schematic representation of mechanism illustrating the conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-metal organic frameworks.

elements.content: Hydrogen-bonding interactions are regarded as one of the most important noncovalent forces (apart from metal–ligand coordination bonds) in supramolecular gels. Thus, the facile formation of Fe-based metallogels could be associated with the presence of formamide along with in situ resulting formic acid, which are well-known hydrogen bond donors. The removal of such species via oxidation is observed to disrupt the gel network which consequently results in the complete gel degradation as observed in the present case. This possibly drives the system to follow a more thermodynamically controlled pathway, which eventually results in the formation of MOF crystals.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen-bonding interactions are regarded as one of the most important noncovalent forces (apart from metal-ligand coordination bonds) in supramolecular gels. Thus, the facile formation of Fe-based metallogels could be associated with the presence of formamide along with in situ resulting formic acid, which are well-known hydrogen bond donors. The removal of such species via oxidation is observed to disrupt the gel network which consequently results in the complete gel degradation as observed in the present case. This possibly drives the system to follow a more thermodynamically controlled pathway, which eventually results in the formation of MOF crystals.

elements.content: In conclusion, a new, simple and efficient route of synthesis of large mountable Fe-based MOF crystals was determined via PdCl2-mediated gel degradation. This study hints the conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-MOFs mediated through formic acid/DMF oxidation. This route paves the way for an efficient synthesis and single crystal structure determination of most of the MOFs, in particular, Fe-based MOFs which are otherwise difficult to synthesize and demand high-resolution PXRD data for their structure determination through Rietveld refinement techniques.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a new, simple and efficient route of synthesis of large mountable Fe-based MOF crystals was determined via PdCl2-mediated gel degradation. This study hints the conversion of Fe-metallogel into Fe-MOFs mediated through formic acid/DMF oxidation. This route paves the way for an efficient synthesis and single crystal structure determination of most of the MOFs, in particular, Fe-based MOFs which are otherwise difficult to synthesize and demand high-resolution PXRD data for their structure determination through Rietveld refinement techniques.

elements.content: Includes description of experimental details of Fe-metallogels and MOFs, rheological studies, TGA, powder XRD profiles for MOFs and reduced palladium residues, SEM images, EDAX reports, and crystallographic information for Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF and Fe-BTC-NMF. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Includes description of experimental details of Fe-metallogels and MOFs, rheological studies, TGA, powder XRD profiles for MOFs and reduced palladium residues, SEM images, EDAX reports, and crystallographic information for Fe-Pd-BTC-DEF and Fe-BTC-NMF. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
A Distinctive PdCl2‑Mediated Transformation
of Fe-Based Metallogels into Metal–Organic Frameworks
